title: Steeped in History and Culture, a Magnificent Hacienda in Mexico City
text:
Listing of the Day

Location: Coyoacan, Mexico City Price: US$13 million*

Hidden behind a high wall in the tranquil Mexico City neighborhood of Coyoacan lies a spacious, painstakingly restored property, perfect for a new owner who is passionate about the city’s—and the country’s—history.

The 22,690-square-foot hacienda—Spanish for estate—dates back almost 500 years, according to property agent Laura de la Torre Skipsey of Mexico Sotheby's International Realty. The original deed was written in Nahuatl, the dominant pre-colonial language of the region and, for a period in the 16th century, belonged to one of the captains of the infamous conquistador Hernán Cortés. For much of its existence it was a working hacienda, growing primarily sugarcane and maize, according to Ms. Skipsey.

In the first half of the 20th century it hosted an art school— the School of Outdoor Painting—founded by Alfredo Ramos Martínez, an early proponent of the Mexican muralism movement. The school inspired artists like Frida Kahlo and her muralist husband Diego Rivera, alongside notable alumni such as David Alfaro Siqueiros and Mardonio Magaña. A painting of the hacienda, dating from this period, is in the collection of Mexico City’s Palacio de Bellas Artes.

More: Resort Living in the U.S. and Mexico Comes Down to One Thing: More

It was completely restored in the early 1980s by its current owner, Elvia Gonzalez Valdes and her husband, Roger Alberto Martinez Peniche, and is currently used as both a residence—the upper floor is private—and for events and weddings and as a film location. It currently has a license to operate as a restaurant, subject to renewal under a new owner, and could be converted into a small boutique hotel, Ms. Skipsey said.

"Whoever buys the hacienda will be the keeper of this historic place," she added. "The value is in the history, the way it has been kept. Very few have been kept in this state and used as private residences.

"It has to be for someone who understands history, loves history and loves Coyoacan. Every corner of the property has something to say, moments to describe," she said.

Stats

The hacienda is a 22,290-square-foot property, which sits on .8 acres of grounds. On the upper floor are four bedrooms, each with its private bathroom—the master suite also boasts a Jacuzzi. There are six full bathrooms and three half-baths in total.

From Penta: Cuban Art Has Its Moment in the Spotlight

Amenities

The property features a game room with a billiard table, which leads out directly to the grounds. The spacious, traditional Mexican-style kitchen features an antique tile mosaic of the patron saint of chefs, San Pascual Bailon.

The hacienda also features an internal patio, complete with a 200-year-old tree, and a wine cellar, which has been converted to a pantry. On the grounds is a small chapel, which is still used as a place of worship and for weddings. There are separate staff quarters, with three rooms, and a functioning water well dating from colonial times.

The property features murals from the students of the school and imported furniture, including a Venetian rococo dining table and magnificent chandeliers. They came from Europe, transported across the Atlantic to Merida by boat, before being brought overland to Coyoacan.

"Every piece of furniture is art," Ms. Skipsey said. It will be sold separately but made available for a new owner.

More: Former New York Yankees Star Jason Giambi Puts Cabo Estate Up for Auction

Neighborhood Notes

When the hacienda was built, Coyoacan wasn’t part of Mexico City, but as the conurbation grew, the delightful, sleepy suburb was enveloped. The neighborhood still retains much of its charm, and life is centered around its famous plaza, which contains a fountain with the figures of two coyotes, a nod to its name, from the Nahuatl language, that is thought to mean the "place of coyotes."

The property is a short stroll through leafy streets to one of Mexico City’s most famous attractions, the Casa Azul (Blue House)—once the home of Kahlo and Rivera. It is now a remarkably well-preserved museum dedicated to the country’s most famous artist couple.

Gonzalez Valdes, who has resided in the property for almost 40 years, said that the hacienda has earned its place in the storied area. Its "history means it’s part of this cultural neighborhood," she said.

Near the Casa Azul is the Trotsky museum—the Soviet dissident had been a houseguest of Kahlo and Rivera after he was exiled and later set up his own residence nearby. He lived there until his death, when he was assassinated in the home.

Also a stone’s throw from the hacienda is the Church of San Juan Bautista, as well as the Mercado Xicotencatl, one of the city’s best markets—it’s packed with fresh fruits, meat and vegetables, street food and artisanal crafts.

*Prices are often given in U.S. dollars rather than the fluctuating Mexican peso.

Listing agent: Laura de la Torre Skipsey, Mexico Sotheby's International Realty
